triples.statement: In February 2012, the Pacific El Niño/Southern Oscillation Applications Climate (PEAC) Center predicted below-normal tropical cyclone activity for the first half of 2012, with no major activity expected until June due to the 2010–2012 La Niña event.
The PEAC Center also suggested that weather patterns would later return to near-normal and that the westward displacement of storms observed in the prior two seasons would not happen.
On March 20, the Hong Kong Observatory predicted that the local typhoon season would probably begin in June because of the La Niña event.
The Hong Kong Observatory also predicted that 5 to 8 storm systems would pass within 500 km of the territory and could potentially have an impact.
On April 11, the Tropical Storm Risk Consortium (TSR) released its initial forecast, predicting a season about 10% below average with 25.5 tropical storms, 15.6 typhoons, and 7.3 intense typhoons.
Later in April, the Shanghai Typhoon Institute (STI) predicted 22 to 24 tropical storms, and in May, TSR revised its forecast to a near-normal season with 8.5 intense typhoons.
In its July update, TSR raised its forecast due to warmer sea surface temperatures, predicting activity about 10% above average with 27.4 tropical storms, 16.7 typhoons, and 9.2 intense typhoons.
The JMA continued to track the depression for several more days, with the final observation occurring on February 20.
Across the affected region, five people died and three were reported missing.
Officials in Ho Chi Minh City reported the destruction of 600 homes and schools.
Over 332 passengers were stranded at ports in the Bicol region because of Mawar.
Due to bad weather, various domestic and international flights had to divert to Clark Air Base instead of NAIA.
The effects of these rains were limited, with only one fatality occurring.
Total economic losses were estimated to be more than ¥8 billion (US$100 million).
Across China, the storm caused one death and total economic losses of CNY 2.25 billion (US$354 million).
In Macau, the storm caused minor roof damage.
The storm killed at least one person in South Korea, while in North Korea, state-run media reported at least eight fatalities.
Flooding from the storm inundated nearly 3,870 homes, leaving more than 16,250 people homeless.
The storm damaged 300 public buildings and 60 factories.
At 16:45 UTC, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the Hurricane Signal, No. 10, which was the first time this signal had been used since Typhoon York in 1999.
Later, Typhoon Vicente made landfall over Taishan in Guangdong, China.
Relatively few buildings in the region were damaged or destroyed.
Many buildings were damaged, and approximately 1.9 million homes lost power.
Losses in South Korea reached ₩420 billion (US$374.3 million), mostly from destroyed apple orchards.
In North Korea, significant damage occurred, with at least 59 people killed and 50 others reported missing.
Nine people drowned offshore after two Chinese vessels sank.
Total economic losses in China were calculated to be CNY 19.82 billion (US$3.126 billion).
On September 17, Sanba made landfall over South Korea.
The extratropical system merged with a front, became an intense hurricane-force low on October 5, reformed near the Aleutian Islands, and dissipated near Alaska on October 11.
At 6:00 pm ICT (11:00 UTC), the storm made landfall over Phú Yên Province in Vietnam.
The remnants of the storm later spawned an area of convection that developed into Depression BOB 01 in the Bay of Bengal.
Fourteen student-mountaineers were rescued from Papaya River Base Camp in Mariveles, Bataan, after being trapped by rains from Gaemi.
Prapiroon completed its transition to an extratropical cyclone 12 hours later, continued northeast, then turned north, and was last observed near the Aleutian Islands on October 23.
Strong winds derailed a train in Quezon.
Bopha subsequently made landfall in Mindanao at the same intensity.

In the North-western Pacific Ocean, both the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assign names to tropical cyclones, which can result in a cyclone having two names.

The Japan Meteorological Agency's RSMC Tokyo—Typhoon Center assigns international names on behalf of the World Meteorological Organization's Typhoon Committee to tropical cyclones with 10-minute sustained wind speeds of 65 km/h (40 mph).

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assigns names to tropical cyclones that move into or form within its area of responsibility (between 135°E and 115°E, and 5°N-25°N), even if the cyclone already has an international name.
The names of significant tropical cyclones are retired by both PAGASA and the Typhoon Committee.
Following the 2012 season, the Typhoon Committee retired the names Vicente and Bopha, which were replaced in 2014 and 2015 with Lan and Ampil for future seasons.
During the season, PAGASA used its own naming scheme for 17 tropical cyclones that either developed within or moved into its defined area of responsibility.
The names were taken from a list that was last used in 2008 and was used again in 2016.
Following the 2012 season, the name Pablo was retired by PAGASA because of the damage and deaths it caused, and was replaced with the name Pepito.
